item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

[quote=“matzie, post:9, topic:546732”]long = 8 bytes

int[2] = 12 bytes {pointer and 2 values}

Item = 10-12 bytes (minimum) (10 if you use a short for itemID) {pointer, item field, and amount field}[/quote]
Unless your running a huge database that should be limited in size you shouldn’t care about the size but about the performance.
So use integers because they are faster and not shorts because they’re 2 bytes less.

item.dc:creator: @matzie matzie
item.description:
@matzie wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:8, topic:546732”][quote author=matzie link=topic=665629.msg4450238#msg4450238 date=1410869553]

The way you have it set up right now, it’s impossible to return two ints from different arrays. (afaik without using some weird method)

You could use a 2d array

ex:

And if you wanted to reference it in another code you could return one of the arrays inside the bigger array.

public static int[][] chestRewards = { {1039, 1}, {995, 1000000} }; public static int[] getReward() { return ChestRewards[(int)(Math.random()*ChestRewards.length)]; }

And elsewhere you’d put

public void spawnItems() { int[] rewardArray = Class.randomChestRewards(); player.addItem(rewardArray[0], rewardArray[1]; }

You’re making it more complex than needed…

Most 317 servers have an Item class, use it…

[code=java]private static Item[] chestRewards = {
new Item(1039, 1), new Item(995, 10000000)
};

public Item getChestReward() {
return chestRewards[Misc.random(chestRewards.length == 0 ? 0 : chestRewards.length - 1)];
}

public void addReward() {// EXAMPLE.
Item theItem = getChestReward();
c.sendMessage(“You got " + ItemAssistant.getItemName(theItem.id) + " x” + theItem.amount + " from the chest!");
}
[/code]

[quote]public Item getChestReward() {
return chestRewards[Misc.random(chestRewards.length == 0 ? 0 : chestRewards.length - 1)];
}[/quote]
If array is size 0 then index 0 will not exist neither.

You could also return a long value >_>'
return (id << 32 | amount);
Reading:

long returnValue = getReward();
int itemID = (int)(returnValue >> 32);
int amount = (int)returnValue;

[/quote]
That was a fudge up on my end. It was supposed to be array size 1, set it to index 0. I messed up typing that part of the method. Sorry.
Also, why use a long? Just want to know your reasoning behind it, not trying to sound like you’re wrong…[/quote]

int[2] = 12 bytes {pointer and 2 values}

Item = 10-12 bytes (minimum) (10 if you use a short for itemID) {pointer, item field, and amount field}
